Prompts: If there are 2 sockets bound to the same IP, does the incoming packet get duplicated to both sockets or only send to 1 randomly?
Answers: When you have two sockets bound to the same IP address (and port), incoming packets won't get duplicated between them. Instead, the behavior depends on a couple of factors:If the sockets are bound to the same port number: In this case, usually, the operating system won't allow you to bind the second socket to the same IP address and port. It will return an error when you try to do so. This is because, generally, the combination of IP address and port must be unique to each socket to avoid ambiguity.If the sockets are bound to different port numbers: In this case, the operating system will direct the incoming packet to the correct socket based on not only the IP address but also the port number. So if two packets arrive with the same IP address but different port numbers, each packet will be directed to the corresponding socket.For UDP multicast: If the sockets are listening for incoming multicast or broadcast UDP packets, then yes, each packet will be delivered to all sockets that are joined to that multicast group or listening for broadcasts, effectively duplicating the packet at the application level.In summary, for unicast TCP and UDP connections, the OS uses the combination of IP address and port to uniquely identify a socket and direct incoming packets appropriately. For multicast and broadcast, the behavior is different and incoming packets can be received by multiple sockets.

Prompts: When does a packet get duplicated and sent to all sockets?
Answers: A packet gets duplicated and sent to all relevant sockets in a few specific scenarios:UDP Multicast and Broadcast: In UDP, if multiple sockets on the same host join the same multicast group or are listening for broadcasts, they will all receive a copy of each incoming multicast or broadcast packet. This essentially duplicates the packet at the application level.SO_REUSEPORT: This is a socket option that, when set, allows multiple sockets on the same host to bind to the same IP address and port number. When a packet arrives, the kernel will duplicate it and send it to all sockets that have bound to that address and port.Note: The behaviour of SO_REUSEPORT can vary between operating systems and is not available on all platforms. For example, on Linux, SO_REUSEPORT allows balancing incoming connections (or packets for UDP) across the sockets, rather than duplicating the incoming data. It is best to check the documentation for the specific platform you are working on.Remember that even when packets are duplicated in this way, they are not duplicated at the network level - each client only receives one copy of the packet. The duplication happens at the application level, with each socket receiving its own copy of the packet data.If the sockets are using TCP, incoming packets will not be duplicated. TCP sockets are connection-oriented, meaning that each connection is associated with a specific pair of IP addresses and port numbers. Therefore, each incoming packet belongs to a particular connection and will be delivered to the socket that is handling that connection.
